questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : SOFTWARE ENGINEERING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"  ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is the primary responsibility of the data scientists at a software company?
question_texts: Which of the following is the primary responsibility of the data scientists at a software company?

options.option_text: To communicate with users and create prototypes.
To shape the terms of service of the software product, software licenses,privacy policy etc.
To analyze data generated from various teams and users in order to assist theorganization in making better decisions.
To address and resolve issues that clients encounter.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is the benefit of using project management tools?
question_texts: Which of the following is the benefit of using project management tools?

options.option_text: It helps to document and archive the knowledge of one project that might berequired in some other project.
It helps all members of the team to get a big picture as well as detailed view ofprogress.
It helps in easy migration of developers between different projects.
It helps the developers to become more productive by using tools like IDEs.

questions.question_text_1: What is velocity from the agile project estimation perspective?
question_texts: What is velocity from the agile project estimation perspective?

options.option_text: Number of user stories per sprint
The time required to complete an agile project
The point assigned to each user story

questions.question_text_1: Consider an eCommerce portal that has been integrated with a payment gateway with a set of APIs. Which of the following debugging strategies involves the task of searching the documentation and code examples to understand the correct use of the APIs?
question_texts: Consider an eCommerce portal that has been integrated with a payment gateway with a set of APIs. Which of the following debugging strategies involves the task of searching the documentation and code examples to understand the correct use of the APIs?

questions.question_text_1: Heroku and Google App Engine are examples of ___________.
question_texts: Heroku and Google App Engine are examples of ___________.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true about the production environment of deployment?
question_texts: Which of the following is true about the production environment of deployment?

options.option_text: It is primarily created for performing integration and system testing.
It is also known as live environment where all the users can interact with thedeployed system.
It is the local environment for individual developers that provides IDEs andother tools.
It exactly resembles the production environment, and it runs on a remotemachine.

questions.question_text_1: In which of the software deployment strategies are changes incrementally rolled out to a small subset of users?
question_texts: In which of the software deployment strategies are changes incrementally rolled out to a small subset of users?

questions.question_text_1: Suppose you are creating a prototype for a web application which is presented on multiple papers as handdrawn UIs of different screens.  In the above case, identify the type of prototype technique you have chosen.
question_texts: Suppose you are creating a prototype for a web application which is presented on multiple papers as handdrawn UIs of different screens.  In the above case, identify the type of prototype technique you have chosen.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose a software organization is designing the UI of a web application for an employee payroll system. For all the icons on the buttons and links, they have chosen various animal pictures. Which one of the following UI evaluation heuristics would be missing in this design?
question_texts: Suppose a software organization is designing the UI of a web application for an employee payroll system. For all the icons on the buttons and links, they have chosen various animal pictures. Which one of the following UI evaluation heuristics would be missing in this design?

questions.question_text_1: Consider an EdTech company that decided to develop an educational portal based on GenAI services. However, there are some requirements that are ambiguous or conflicting. As a result, the company has arranged a meeting of all the managers of different departments to discuss the issues and requirements and reach some consensus on them. In the given scenario, which of the following requirement gathering techniques is in use?
question_texts: Consider an EdTech company that decided to develop an educational portal based on GenAI services. However, there are some requirements that are ambiguous or conflicting. As a result, the company has arranged a meeting of all the managers of different departments to discuss the issues and requirements and reach some consensus on them. In the given scenario, which of the following requirement gathering techniques is in use?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the SMART characteristics of user stories specifies that if the implementation of a user story is not possible in one iteration, then subdivide the story into smaller ones?
question_texts: Which of the SMART characteristics of user stories specifies that if the implementation of a user story is not possible in one iteration, then subdivide the story into smaller ones?

questions.question_text_1: A software company has to develop a job portal that will allow job seekers to apply for different organizations at different positions. Therefore, the entire task of the project is divided into different modules, and the interactions between the modules are outlined. Which phase of the SDLC is the software currently in?
question_texts: A software company has to develop a job portal that will allow job seekers to apply for different organizations at different positions. Therefore, the entire task of the project is divided into different modules, and the interactions between the modules are outlined. Which phase of the SDLC is the software currently in?

options.option_text: Has high coupling and high cohesion
Has high coupling and low cohesion
Has low coupling and high cohesion
Has low coupling and low cohesion

questions.question_text_1: Consider a mobile application for enhancing image quality. The image quality enhancement application is made up of several data filters. The filters are connected one after another. Each filter processes the data it receives and sends the output to the next filter in line. Which type of architecture is used to design the data processing software?
question_texts: Consider a mobile application for enhancing image quality. The image quality enhancement application is made up of several data filters. The filters are connected one after another. Each filter processes the data it receives and sends the output to the next filter in line. Which type of architecture is used to design the data processing software?

options.option_text: Lack of experience building banking applications
Product not competitive in the market

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are considered as the primary objective(s) of monitoring tools for enhancing the performance of web applications?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are considered as the primary objective(s) of monitoring tools for enhancing the performance of web applications?

options.option_text: It stores the results of common operations in memory.
It helps to understand customer behaviour.
It can be used to analyze page resources, find optimization suggestions, checkSEO and accessibility metrics and calculate your performance score.
D and E inherit from A

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Software Engineering (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)**
- **Phases**:
  - Requirements Gathering (e.g., Focus Groups, Questionnaires, Interviews)
  - Design (Modularization, Coupling/Cohesion)
  - Development (Coding, Debugging)
  - Testing (Unit, Integration, System)
  - Deployment (Strategies: Blue/Green, Canary, Versioned)
  - Maintenance
- **Key Concepts**:
  - **Coupling & Cohesion**:
    - **High Coupling**: Modules are highly dependent (e.g., sharing large data chunks).
    - **Low Cohesion**: Functions in a module serve unrelated purposes.
  - **Prototyping Techniques**:
    - **Storyboards** (Hand-drawn UI flows)
    - **Paper Prototype** (Low-fidelity mockups)
    - **Digital Mockups** (High-fidelity designs)
    - **Interactive Prototype** (Clickable prototypes)

### **B. Agile & Project Management**
- **Velocity**:
  - **Definition**: Number of story points completed per sprint.
  - **Formula**:
    ```
    Velocity = Σ (Story Points Completed in a Sprint)
    ```
- **User Stories (SMART Criteria)**:
  - **Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Timeboxed**
  - **Achievable**: If a story is too large, break it into smaller sub-stories.
- **Project Management Tools**:
  - Benefits:
    - Big-picture & detailed progress tracking.
    - Knowledge archiving for future projects.

### **C. Software Metrics**
- **Cyclomatic Complexity (McCabe’s Metric)**:
  - **Definition**: Measures code complexity based on independent paths.
  - **Formula**:
    ```
    V(G) = E - N + 2P
    ```
    - `E` = Edges (control flow paths)
    - `N` = Nodes (statements)
    - `P` = Connected components (usually 1)
  - **Rules of Thumb**:
    - `V ≤ 10` → Simple
    - `10 < V ≤ 20` → Moderate
    - `V > 20` → Complex (refactor needed)
- **Raw Metrics**:
  - **Lines of Code (LOC)**: Includes code, comments, and whitespace.
- **Halstead’s Metrics**:
  - Measures program vocabulary (operators/operands).

### **D. Debugging Strategies**
- **Blackbox Debugging**:
  - Debugging without internal code knowledge (e.g., checking API docs).
- **Input Manipulation**:
  - Testing with different inputs to isolate bugs.
- **Forward/Backward Debugging**:
  - **Forward**: Start from input, trace execution.
  - **Backward**: Start from error, trace backward.

### **E. Deployment Strategies**
| Strategy          | Description                                                                 |
|-------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Blue/Green**    | Two identical environments; switch traffic between them.                  |
| **Canary**        | Roll out changes to a small user subset first.                             |
| **Versioned**     | Multiple versions run simultaneously (e.g., API versioning).              |

### **F. Software Architectures**
- **Pipe & Filter**:
  - Data processed sequentially through filters (e.g., image processing).
- **Client-Server**:
  - Central server handles requests from clients.
- **Model-View-Controller (MVC)**:
  - Separates data (Model), UI (View), and logic (Controller).
- **Peer-to-Peer (P2P)**:
  - Decentralized; nodes communicate directly.

### **G. Design Patterns**
- **Strategy Pattern**:
  - **Purpose**: Encapsulate interchangeable algorithms (e.g., payment methods).
  - **Components**:
    - **Context** (uses strategy)
    - **Strategy Interface** (common contract)
    - **Concrete Strategies** (implementations)
  - **Benefits**:
    - Flexibility (add new strategies without modifying context).
    - Open/Closed Principle compliance.

### **H. Testing Techniques**
- **Equivalence Class Partitioning**:
  - Divide input into valid/invalid classes (e.g., `months ≤ 0`, `0 < months < 12`).
- **Branch Coverage**:
  - Test all possible branches (e.g., `if`, `else`, loops).
- **Multiple Condition Coverage**:
  - Test all combinations of conditions (e.g., `n < 0`, `n == 0 || n == 1`).

### **I. Risk Assessment**
- **Risk Probability**:
  - `Assessed Risk = Probability × Impact`
  - **Example**:
    | Risk                          | Impact | Probability | Assessed Risk |
    |-------------------------------|--------|-------------|---------------|
    | Personnel Shortfall           | 1      | 0.6         | **0.6**       |
    | Budget Slippage               | 3      | 0.9         | 2.7           |

### **J. Cloud Computing Models**
| Model               | Description                                                                 | Examples                     |
|---------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **IaaS**           | Infrastructure (VMs, storage) as a service.                              | AWS EC2, Azure VMs           |
| **PaaS**           | Platform (runtime, OS) as a service.                                      | Heroku, Google App Engine    |
| **SaaS**           | Software (applications) as a service.                                     | Gmail, Slack                 |
| **Bare Metal**     | Physical servers without virtualization.                                  | IBM Cloud Bare Metal         |

### **K. UX/UI Heuristics**
- **Nielsen’s 10 Heuristics**:
  - **Recognition over Recall**: Minimize memory load (e.g., intuitive icons).
  - **Flexibility & Efficiency**: Accelerators for expert users.
  - **Aesthetic & Minimalist Design**: Avoid clutter.

---

## **2. Key Equations**
### **A. COCOMO Model (Cost Estimation)**
- **Formula**:
  ```
  Effort (E) = a × (KLOC)^b  [Person-Months]
  Cost = E × Salary per staff
  ```
- **Constants**:
  | Project Type   | a    | b    |
  |----------------|------|------|
  | Organic        | 2.4  | 1.05 |
  | Semi-Detached  | 3.0  | 1.12 |
  | Embedded       | 3.6  | 1.20 |

- **Example (Embedded, 300 KLOC, Salary = ₹50,000)**:
  ```
  E = 3.6 × (300)^1.20 ≈ 3.6 × 400 ≈ 1440 Person-Months
  Cost = 1440 × ₹50,000 ≈ ₹16,90,00,000
  ```

### **B. Cyclomatic Complexity**
- **Example (Selection Sort)**:
  ```python
  def ssort(items, n):
      for it in range(n):          # +1 (loop)
          min_i = it
          for i in range(it+1, n): # +1 (nested loop)
              if items[i] < items[min_i]: # +1 (condition)
                  min_i = i
          (items[it], items[min_i]) = (items[min_i], items[it])
  ```
  - **Complexity**: `2 (loops) + 1 (if) + 1 = 4`

---

## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: SDLC Phases & Key Concepts**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Software Development Lifecycle] --> B[Requirements Gathering]
    A --> C[Design]
    A --> D[Development]
    A --> E[Testing]
    A --> F[Deployment]
    A --> G[Maintenance]

    B --> B1[Focus Groups]
    B --> B2[Interviews]
    B --> B3[Questionnaires]

    C --> C1[Modularization]
    C --> C2[Coupling & Cohesion]
    C --> C3[Architecture Patterns]

    D --> D1[Coding]
    D --> D2[Debugging Strategies]

    E --> E1[Unit Testing]
    E --> E2[Integration Testing]
    E --> E3[System Testing]

    F --> F1[Blue/Green]
    F --> F2[Canary]
    F --> F3[Versioned]
```

### **Graph 2: Agile & Project Management**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Agile Project Management] --> B[Velocity]
    A --> C[User Stories]
    A --> D[Project Tools]

    B --> B1[Story Points per Sprint]

    C --> C1[SMART Criteria]
    C --> C2[Achievable: Break into Sub-Stories]

    D --> D1[Progress Tracking]
    D --> D2[Knowledge Archiving]
```

### **Graph 3: Software Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Software Metrics] --> B[Cyclomatic Complexity]
    A --> C[Lines of Code]
    A --> D[Halstead's Metrics]

    B --> B1[V = E - N + 2P]
    B --> B2[Independent Paths]

    C --> C1[Raw Metrics]
    C --> C2[Includes Comments & Whitespace]
```

### **Graph 4: Debugging & Testing**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Debugging] --> B[Blackbox]
    A --> C[Input Manipulation]
    A --> D[Forward/Backward]

    B --> B1[API Documentation]

    E[Testing] --> E1[Equivalence Partitioning]
    E --> E2[Branch Coverage]
    E --> E3[Multiple Condition Coverage]
```

### **Graph 5: Cloud & Deployment**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Cloud Models] --> B[IaaS]
    A --> C[PaaS]
    A --> D[SaaS]
    A --> E[Bare Metal]

    B --> B1[AWS EC2]
    C --> C1[Heroku]
    D --> D1[Gmail]

    F[Deployment Strategies] --> F1[Blue/Green]
    F --> F2[Canary]
    F --> F3[Versioned]
```

### **Graph 6: Design Patterns**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Strategy Pattern] --> B[Context]
    A --> C[Strategy Interface]
    A --> D[Concrete Strategies]

    B --> B1[PaymentManager]
    C --> C1[Payable]
    D --> D1[PayByCash]
    D --> D2[PayByUPI]
```

---
## **4. Exam Tips**
1. **Focus on Equations**:
   - COCOMO, Cyclomatic Complexity, and Effort Calculation.
2. **Diagrams**:
   - UML (Class, Interaction, State Machine).
   - Deployment Strategies.
3. **Key Definitions**:
   - Velocity, Coupling/Cohesion, PaaS vs. IaaS.
4. **Testing**:
   - Equivalence Class, Branch Coverage, Multiple Condition Coverage.
5. **Design Patterns**:
   - Strategy Pattern (components & benefits).
